MEMORANDUM ORDER: 1) Defs' Sealed Motion for Order Granting Def Kenton County's Request for an Updated Independent Medical Examination of Plfs 198, which the Court construes as a Motion to Compel a second Rule 35 examination of Plfs, is granted; 2) The examination of Plfs S.R. and L.G. shall be performed by Dr. Allan Josephson at the Bingham Clinic, University of Louisville School of Medicine, 200 East Chestnut Street, Louisville, KY 40202; 3) The examination of S.R. and L.G. shall be conducted separately from each other, but each child shall be accompanied by his/her mother, as next friend; 4) The examination of S.R. and L.G. shall consist of an updated clinical interview of each child and his/her parent, including but not limited to the taking of an oral history and observation by Dr. Josephson; 5) The parties shall agree upon a date, as soon as possible, for the examinations. Each examination shall begin at 10:00 a.m. and conclude no later than 2:00 p.m. that same date. Plfs may have a brief lunch break during the examination period; 6) Plfs shall either be reimbursed by Def for mileage and reasonable expenses (such as lunch) or Plfs may elect to have Def provide transportation and/or acceptable lunches for Plfs and their next friends; and 7) Def shall provide Plfs' counsel with a supplemental report regarding the updated examinations within 10 days of their occurrence. Signed by Magistrate Judge Candace J. Smith on 2/12/2018.(ECO)cc: COR (Entered: 02/12/2018)

original_case_data.name: S.R. v. Kenton County
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: Two minors with disabilities enrolled within elementary schools within the Covington Independent Public Schools District.
original_case_data.summary:
On August 3, 2015, two minor children with disabilities filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky. The plaintiffs sued the Kenton County Sheriff's Office, the Sheriff for Kenton County (in only his official capacity), and the Sheriff's Office's School Resource Officer (in his official and individual capacities) under 42 U.S.C § 1983 and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act. The plaintiffs, represented by the ACLU and private counsel, sought injunctive relief, declaratory relief and damages, claiming the defendant used unnecessary and excessive physical restraint and handcuffs on schoolchildren with disabilities. The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' actions constituted unreasonable seizure and excessive force in violation of plaintiffs' rights under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments. The plaintiffs also claimed that the defendants discriminated against the plaintiffs based on their disabilities and failed to accommodate their disabilities.

On September 9, 2015, the defendants filed a joint motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim. On September 30, 2015, the plaintiffs filed a cross motion for judgment on the pleadings.

On December 28, 2015, Judge William O. Bertelsman denied the defendants' motion to dismiss without prejudice. The Court found that the plaintiffs adequately pleaded a constitutional violation in order to make out a § 1983 claim. The plaintiffs also adequately pleaded plausible claims for discrimination under Title II.

In October 2016, both parties filed cross motions for partial summary judgment. Additionally, the defendants filed a motion to sever the claims of the two students on September 14, 2017. Judge Bertelsman denied the defendants' motion to sever because of the substantial factual similarities between the two handcuffing situations and the existence of a common question of law: whether the elbow-cuffing of these children was unconstitutional.

On October 11, 2017, Judge Bertelsman ruled on the parties' cross motions for partial summary judgment. Judge Bertelsman held for the plaintiffs on their claims of unlawful seizure and excessive use of force and municipal liability against Kenton County for those violations. The Court applied the Graham factors and found that although the severity of the crime weighed in favor of the defendants, the other factors -- whether the children posed an immediate threat to themselves or others; the age and stature of the children; and the method of handcuffing -- weighed in favor of the plaintiffs.

However, Judge Bertelsman ruled against the plaintiffs on their ADA discrimination and reasonable accommodation claims. The Court found that no reasonable jury could find that the defendants' handcuffing of the plaintiffs would not have occurred "but

for" their alleged disabilities, as opposed to their behavior on the days in question.

Additionally, Judge Bertelsman held for the defendants on the issue of qualified immunity. Although the Court said it was a close call, it found that the plaintiffs failed to show that it was clearly established that the handcuffing was unconstitutional. The Court found that the Supreme Court precedent that the plaintiffs relied on was too generalized and that the plaintiffs failed to cite to any Sixth Circuit precedent.

On February 7, 2018, the defendants (in their official capacities) filed a motion to dismiss the plaintiffs' constitutional claims under § 1983 for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, claiming state sovereign immunity under the Eleventh Amendment. Before hearing oral argument on the issue of damages, the Court noted that it would take the defendants' motion to dismiss under advisement.

However, following a settlement conference on April 13, 2018, the parties privately reached an agreement whereby the defendants agreed to pay more than $337,000 in damages. The Court dismissed the action with prejudice on November 1, 2018, ordering that each party must pay their own costs.
original_case_data.summary_short: In August 2015, two minor children with disabilities filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky. The plaintiffs sued under to 42 U.S.C § 1983 and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act against the Kenton County Sheriff's Office and the Office's School Resource Officer claiming use of unnecessary and excessive physical restraint and handcuffing on the children. In October 2017, the Court dismissed the plaintiffs' ADA claims, held in favor of the plaintiffs on their excessive force claims, and held that the officers in their individual capacities were entitled to qualified immunity. In 2018, the parties agreed to privately settle the case and the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs more than $337,000 in damages.

The plaintiffs sued the Kenton County Sheriff's Office, the Sheriff for Kenton County (in his official capacity), and the Sheriff's Office's School Resource Officer (in his official and individual capacities) under 42 U.S.C § 1983 and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act. Plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, declaratory relief, and damages, alleging defendants used unnecessary and excessive physical restraint and handcuffs on schoolchildren with disabilities. They claimed these actions constituted unreasonable seizure and excessive force in violation of their Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights. Plaintiffs also asserted claims for disability discrimination and failure to accommodate their disabilities.

3.transformed_text:
**Executive Summary: Litigation Update - Kenton County Sheriff's Office Case**

The lawsuit by two minor children with disabilities against the Kenton County Sheriff's Office and its personnel, alleging excessive force (42 U.S.C. § 1983) and disability discrimination (Title II ADA), concluded with a private settlement where defendants paid over $337,000 in damages, leading to dismissal.

Key Results:

*   **Initial Pleadings & Pre-Trial Rulings:** The District Court denied defendants' motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim, finding plaintiffs adequately pleaded constitutional violations under § 1983 (unreasonable seizure, excessive force violating Fourth/Fourteenth Amendments) and plausible Title II ADA claims. A motion to sever the students' claims was also denied.
*   **Partial Summary Judgment - Mixed Outcomes:** The Court granted partial summary judgment to plaintiffs on their unlawful seizure, excessive force, and municipal liability claims against Kenton County, applying the Graham factors. Conversely, the Court ruled against plaintiffs on their Title II ADA discrimination and reasonable accommodation claims, finding no "but for" causation between their alleged disabilities and the challenged conduct, but rather their behavior.
*   **Qualified Immunity Granted:** Defendants were granted qualified immunity. The Court found plaintiffs failed to demonstrate the unconstitutionality of the handcuffing was clearly established by precedent, citing generalized Supreme Court precedent and a lack of specific Sixth Circuit authority.
*   **Settlement & Dismissal:** Following a settlement conference, and prior to a ruling on defendants' pending Eleventh Amendment sovereign immunity motion to dismiss § 1983 claims, the parties privately settled. Defendants paid over $337,000 in damages, leading to the action's dismissal with prejudice, with each party bearing their own costs.

1.transformed_text:
On August 3, 2015, two students with disabilities filed a lawsuit in federal court in Kentucky. They sued the Kenton County Sheriff's Office, the Kenton County Sheriff (in his official role), and a School Resource Officer (both in his official role and as an individual). The lawsuit was filed under federal civil rights law (42 U.S.C. § 1983) and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). The students, represented by the ACLU and private lawyers, sought court orders and money damages. They claimed the defendants used excessive physical restraint and handcuffs on disabled schoolchildren unnecessarily. The students alleged these actions amounted to an unlawful arrest and excessive force, violating their rights under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments. They also claimed the defendants discriminated against them due to their disabilities and failed to provide reasonable adjustments.

On September 9, 2015, the defendants jointly asked the court to dismiss the case, arguing the lawsuit didn't present a valid legal claim. On September 30, 2015, the students filed their own request for a ruling in their favor based on the initial court filings.

On December 28, 2015, Judge William O. Bertelsman denied the defendants' request to dismiss the case. This denial was "without prejudice," meaning the students could still pursue their claims. The Court found that the students had properly stated a constitutional violation to support their civil rights claim. They had also properly stated believable claims of discrimination under the ADA.

In October 2016, both sides asked the court for a partial ruling in their favor without a full trial. On September 14, 2017, the defendants also asked to separate the claims of the two students. Judge Bertelsman denied this request. He noted the strong factual similarities between the two handcuffing incidents. He also pointed to a common legal question: whether the "elbow-cuffing" of these children was unconstitutional.

On October 11, 2017, Judge Bertelsman ruled on the parties' requests for partial summary judgment. He ruled in favor of the students on their claims of unlawful arrest and excessive use of force. He also found Kenton County responsible for these violations. The Court applied specific legal factors, known as the "Graham factors." It found that while the seriousness of the alleged offense supported the defendants, other factors favored the students. These factors included whether the children posed an immediate threat, their age and size, and how they were handcuffed.

However, Judge Bertelsman ruled against the students on their ADA discrimination and reasonable adjustment claims. The Court concluded that no reasonable jury would find the handcuffing happened *because* of their disabilities. Instead, it was due to their behavior on those specific days. Additionally, Judge Bertelsman ruled in favor of the defendants regarding "qualified immunity." This is a legal protection for government officials. Although the Court called it a "close call," it found the students did not show that this type of handcuffing was clearly established as unconstitutional. The Court stated that the Supreme Court rulings the students cited were too broad. It also noted that the students failed to provide any specific rulings from the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals.

On February 7, 2018, the defendants (in their official roles) filed another request to dismiss the students' constitutional claims under § 1983. They argued the court lacked the authority to hear the case, citing "state sovereign immunity" under the Eleventh Amendment. Before a hearing on the amount of damages, the Court stated it would consider the defendants' request to dismiss.

However, after a settlement meeting on April 13, 2018, the parties privately reached an agreement. The defendants agreed to pay over $337,000 in damages. The Court permanently closed the case on November 1, 2018. It also ordered that each side would pay their own legal costs.

On August 3, 2015, two students with disabilities filed a lawsuit in federal court in Kentucky. Their lawsuit was based on a federal law that protects people's civil rights, and also on the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), which makes sure people with disabilities aren't discriminated against. The students, with help from the ACLU (a group that protects civil liberties) and their own lawyers, asked the court to order certain changes and to pay them money. They claimed the defendants used too much physical restraint and handcuffs on disabled schoolchildren without good reason. The students said these actions were like an illegal arrest and using too much force, which went against their basic rights protected by the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments of the Constitution (which cover things like fair treatment and protection from unreasonable searches). They also claimed the defendants treated them unfairly because of their disabilities and didn't make necessary adjustments.

On September 9, 2015, the people being sued (the defendants) together asked the judge to dismiss the case, saying the lawsuit didn't have enough legal reasons to continue. A few weeks later, on September 30, 2015, the students asked the judge to rule in their favor right away, based on the papers already filed in court.

On December 28, 2015, Judge William O. Bertelsman said 'no' to the defendants' request to throw out the case. He said this denial was "without prejudice," which is a legal way of saying the students were still allowed to continue their lawsuit. The judge decided that the students had clearly described how their constitutional rights might have been violated, which was enough to support their civil rights claim. They also had believable claims of discrimination under the ADA.

In October 2016, both sides asked the court to make some decisions in their favor without having to go through a full trial. Then, on September 14, 2017, the defendants also asked to split the two students' lawsuits into separate cases. But Judge Bertelsman said no to this request. He pointed out that the two handcuffing incidents were very similar. And he noted there was one main legal question: was the way these children were "elbow-cuffed" against the Constitution?

On October 11, 2017, Judge Bertelsman made his decisions on those requests for partial rulings. He agreed with the students that they might have been illegally arrested and that too much force was used. He also said that Kenton County could be held responsible for these actions. The judge used a specific set of rules, called the "Graham factors," to make his decision. He found that even though how serious the alleged offense was helped the defendants' side, other things supported the students. These other things included whether the children were an immediate danger, their age and size, and how they were handcuffed.

However, Judge Bertelsman ruled against the students on their ADA discrimination and reasonable adjustment claims. The judge decided that no fair jury would believe the handcuffing happened *because* of their disabilities. Instead, he thought it was because of how they acted on those particular days. Also, Judge Bertelsman agreed with the defendants on something called "qualified immunity." This is a legal protection for government officials. It's like a shield that protects them from being sued personally unless their actions clearly violated someone's rights that were already established by law. Even though the judge said it was a "close call," he found the students couldn't show that this specific way of handcuffing was already clearly understood to be against the Constitution. He said the examples from the Supreme Court that the students used were too broad. And he pointed out that the students didn't provide any specific rulings from the appeals court in their region (the Sixth Circuit).

On February 7, 2018, the defendants (acting in their official roles) filed another request to dismiss the students' claims about their constitutional rights. They argued the court couldn't hear the case because of "state sovereign immunity," a rule from the Eleventh Amendment of the Constitution that generally protects states from being sued in federal court. Before a hearing that was supposed to decide how much money the students should get, the judge said he would think about the defendants' request to dismiss the case.

However, after a meeting to try and settle the case on April 13, 2018, both sides reached a private agreement. The defendants agreed to pay the students over $337,000. The court officially closed the case for good on November 1, 2018. It also ordered that each side would pay for their own lawyers.

0.text:
On August 3, 2015, two minor children with disabilities filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky. The plaintiffs sued the Kenton County Sheriff's Office, the Sheriff for Kenton County (in only his official capacity), and the Sheriff's Office's School Resource Officer (in his official and individual capacities) under 42 U.S.C § 1983 and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act. The plaintiffs, represented by the ACLU and private counsel, sought injunctive relief, declaratory relief and damages, claiming the defendant used unnecessary and excessive physical restraint and handcuffs on schoolchildren with disabilities. The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' actions constituted unreasonable seizure and excessive force in violation of plaintiffs' rights under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments. The plaintiffs also claimed that the defendants discriminated against the plaintiffs based on their disabilities and failed to accommodate their disabilities.

On September 9, 2015, the defendants filed a joint motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim. On September 30, 2015, the plaintiffs filed a cross motion for judgment on the pleadings.

On December 28, 2015, Judge William O. Bertelsman denied the defendants' motion to dismiss without prejudice. The Court found that the plaintiffs adequately pleaded a constitutional violation in order to make out a § 1983 claim. The plaintiffs also adequately pleaded plausible claims for discrimination under Title II.

In October 2016, both parties filed cross motions for partial summary judgment. Additionally, the defendants filed a motion to sever the claims of the two students on September 14, 2017. Judge Bertelsman denied the defendants' motion to sever because of the substantial factual similarities between the two handcuffing situations and the existence of a common question of law: whether the elbow-cuffing of these children was unconstitutional.

On October 11, 2017, Judge Bertelsman ruled on the parties' cross motions for partial summary judgment. Judge Bertelsman held for the plaintiffs on their claims of unlawful seizure and excessive use of force and municipal liability against Kenton County for those violations. The Court applied the Graham factors and found that although the severity of the crime weighed in favor of the defendants, the other factors -- whether the children posed an immediate threat to themselves or others; the age and stature of the children; and the method of handcuffing -- weighed in favor of the plaintiffs.

However, Judge Bertelsman ruled against the plaintiffs on their ADA discrimination and reasonable accommodation claims. The Court found that no reasonable jury could find that the defendants' handcuffing of the plaintiffs would not have occurred "but

for" their alleged disabilities, as opposed to their behavior on the days in question.

Additionally, Judge Bertelsman held for the defendants on the issue of qualified immunity. Although the Court said it was a close call, it found that the plaintiffs failed to show that it was clearly established that the handcuffing was unconstitutional. The Court found that the Supreme Court precedent that the plaintiffs relied on was too generalized and that the plaintiffs failed to cite to any Sixth Circuit precedent.

On February 7, 2018, the defendants (in their official capacities) filed a motion to dismiss the plaintiffs' constitutional claims under § 1983 for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, claiming state sovereign immunity under the Eleventh Amendment. Before hearing oral argument on the issue of damages, the Court noted that it would take the defendants' motion to dismiss under advisement.

However, following a settlement conference on April 13, 2018, the parties privately reached an agreement whereby the defendants agreed to pay more than $337,000 in damages. The Court dismissed the action with prejudice on November 1, 2018, ordering that each party must pay their own costs.

1.transformed_text:
In August 2015, two minor children with disabilities, represented by the ACLU and private counsel, initiated a legal challenge against the Kenton County Sheriff's Office, its Sheriff, and a School Resource Officer. Their purpose was to seek justice and protection, alleging that they had been subjected to unnecessary and excessive physical restraint and handcuffing at school, acts they believed violated their Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights against unreasonable seizure and excessive force. They also contended that these actions constituted discrimination and a failure to accommodate their disabilities under Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act, seeking not only financial compensation but also court orders to prevent future abuses.

The defendants quickly responded in September 2015 by seeking to have the case dismissed, arguing that the children's claims, even if true, did not establish a legal basis for relief. This was a strategic move to prevent the case from proceeding further. In turn, the plaintiffs filed their own motion, asserting that the facts as presented in the initial filings were so clear that they were entitled to a judgment in their favor without the need for a full trial. By December 2015, Judge William O. Bertelsman allowed the case to move forward, rejecting the defendants' attempt to end it prematurely. He concluded that the children had indeed presented sufficiently strong arguments to suggest a constitutional violation and plausible claims of disability discrimination, signaling that their grievances deserved a full hearing.

As the case progressed into 2016, both sides sought to resolve key aspects of the dispute without a full trial by filing motions for partial summary judgment, each hoping to secure a victory on specific claims based on the evidence gathered. In a separate strategic maneuver in September 2017, the defendants attempted to separate the claims of the two students, perhaps hoping to diminish the impact of their combined allegations. However, Judge Bertelsman rejected this effort, recognizing the fundamental similarities in their experiences and the shared legal question of whether the handcuffing was unconstitutional.

In October 2017, Judge Bertelsman delivered a significant ruling, affirming the children's core claims of unlawful seizure and excessive force. He found that the evidence strongly supported the plaintiffs' position, particularly considering the children's age, stature, and the method of restraint, thus holding Kenton County liable for these violations. This was a pivotal moment, validating the children's experience of undue force. Yet, the judge did not find in their favor on the claims of disability discrimination. He concluded that the evidence did not sufficiently prove that the handcuffing occurred *because of* their disabilities, suggesting instead that the actions were a response to their behavior at the time. Furthermore, the court granted the defendants qualified immunity, a legal protection for government officials unless their actions clearly violate established law. Though acknowledging it was a difficult decision, the judge determined that the plaintiffs had not demonstrated that the unconstitutionality of such handcuffing was so clearly established in prior legal precedent that the officers should have known their actions were unlawful.

As the case neared a potential damages hearing in early 2018, the defendants made another attempt to halt the proceedings, asserting that the court lacked the authority to hear the constitutional claims due to state sovereign immunity. However, the protracted legal battle ultimately concluded not with a final court ruling, but through a negotiated settlement. In April 2018, after a settlement conference, the parties reached a private agreement, with the defendants consenting to pay over $337,000 in damages, bringing the case to a close in November 2018.

The court, led by Judge William O. Bertelsman, grappled with the children's claims. original_case_data.name: Inmates of Judge John J. Connelly Youth Center v. Dukakis
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
original_case_data.summary:
In 1975, juveniles in custody of the Department of Youth Services (DYS) at the Judge J. Connelly Youth Center (Roslindale) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Governor of Massachusetts. The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief from allegedly unconstitutional conditions at Roslindale. The Juvenile Court Advocacy Program, and the Massachusetts Defenders Committee represented the plaintiffs.

After pretrial conferences, the parties entered into a Consent Decree. On April 2, 1976, the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts (Judge Wendell Arthur Garrity, Jr.) ordered a Consent Decree as binding judgment in the case.

The Consent Decree provided that: DYS would stop commingling pretrial detainees with committed juveniles awaiting placement; parents would be notified as soon as a juvenile entered the Roslindale for detention, and the attorney for detainee would be determined; detainees could send and receive mail to and from any person, and parcels could only be opened in the presence of the addressee to check for contraband; Roslindale would furnish all items necessary to write and send letters, including postage for seven first class letters per week; twice a week, two-hour visitation periods would be available for parents and guardians; attorneys and clergy could visit at any time between 9:00 A.M. and 7:00 P.M. seven days a week; local telephone calls of five-minute duration would be available six days a week; current and future employees would be screened for emotional fitness to work with children in a custodial setting; each detainee would be assigned a counselor to assist them with any problems arising from detention, and for each 45 detainees there would be a counseling supervisor; all employees were to undergo regular in-service training; individual education needs would be met for each detainee, with class sizes not to exceed 12 detainees; each detainee would be examined by a doctor or registered nurse with 24 hours of admission to Roslindale, and at least every four months afterwards; psychiatric and emergency medical treatment would be made available to each detainee; each detainee was to have at least 75 square feet of personal space, and there was to be a common room per each 20 detainees; upon admission, each detainee would receive a clean room, and be responsible for cleaning up after that; each student would receive a minimum of two hours outdoor recreation on school days, and four hours on non-school days; games, books, and periodicals would be provided to detainees; mandatory sleeping hours would not exceed 8 hours per night; new detainees would be provided with clean mattresses and bedding, as well as towels, toothbrushes and toothpaste; bedding would be cleaned weekly; daily showers or baths would be available to all detainees, with towels changed twice weekly; breakfast and an evening meal would be provided to all detainees, with an snack available after the evening meal, if served before 5:00 P.M.; corporal punishment was strictly forbidden; permitted and proscribed behavior was to be made clear to all detainees upon admission to Roslindale; and any restriction of rights due to behavior must arise from written rules available to detainees, and a hearing must be held on the matter as soon as possible.

The defendants had 8 months to bring Roslindale within full compliance of the Consent Decree, or be subject to closure. Five persons were appointed to a Monitoring Board for 2 years which would submit findings and recommendations to both parties bi-monthly for the first 8 months, and quarterly after that. The Court (Judge Garrity) retained jurisdiction over the matter. There is no docket or further information about the disposition of the case.

Following pretrial conferences, the parties entered into a Consent Decree, which the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts (Judge Wendell Arthur Garrity, Jr.) ordered as binding judgment on April 2, 1976.

Key provisions included: prohibiting the commingling of pretrial detainees with committed juveniles awaiting placement; ensuring parental notification upon a juvenile's admission and determination of legal representation; establishing rights for detainees to send and receive mail, with parcel inspection limited to the addressee's presence for contraband checks, and providing necessary writing materials and postage. The decree also set forth requirements for regular visitation periods for parents, guardians, attorneys, and clergy, and access to local telephone calls.

Regarding staff and services, the decree required screening of employees for emotional fitness, assignment of counselors to detainees with appropriate supervisory ratios (one supervisor per 45 detainees), and regular in-service training for all staff. Educational needs were to be met for each detainee, with class sizes not exceeding 12. Medical provisions included examinations by a doctor or registered nurse within 24 hours of admission and every four months thereafter, along with access to psychiatric and emergency medical treatment.

Living conditions and hygiene standards were also detailed, requiring at least 75 square feet of personal space per detainee, a common room per 20 detainees, and clean rooms upon admission with ongoing cleaning responsibility. The decree mandated minimum outdoor recreation hours on school and non-school days, provision of games, books, and periodicals, and a maximum of 8 hours of mandatory sleeping per night. Detainees were to receive clean mattresses, bedding, towels, toothbrushes, and toothpaste, with weekly bedding changes and daily showers/baths with twice-weekly towel changes. Provisions for breakfast, an evening meal, and a snack were also included.

Finally, the Consent Decree strictly forbade corporal punishment and required clear communication of permitted and proscribed behavior to all detainees upon admission. Any restriction of rights due to behavior had to arise from written rules available to detainees, necessitating a prompt hearing.

The defendants were given 8 months to achieve full compliance with the Consent Decree, or Roslindale would face closure. A five-person Monitoring Board was appointed for 2 years to oversee compliance, submitting findings and recommendations bi-monthly for the first 8 months, then quarterly. The Court (Judge Garrity) retained jurisdiction over the matter. No further docket information or disposition details are available for the case.

1.transformed_text:
In 1975, young people held by the Department of Youth Services (DYS) at the Judge J. Connelly Youth Center (Roslindale) filed a group lawsuit in the federal court in Massachusetts against the Governor. The young people asked the court to declare the conditions at Roslindale illegal and order changes, claiming they were unconstitutional. The Juvenile Court Advocacy Program and the Massachusetts Defenders Committee represented these young people.

After discussions before the trial, both sides agreed to a "Consent Decree." On April 2, 1976, the federal court in Massachusetts (Judge Wendell Arthur Garrity, Jr.) approved this Consent Decree as a final, binding decision in the case.

The Consent Decree stated that: DYS would no longer mix young people awaiting trial with those already sentenced and waiting for a permanent placement. Parents would be told as soon as a young person arrived at Roslindale, and the young person's lawyer would be identified. Young people could send and receive mail from anyone; packages could only be opened with the recipient present, to check for illegal items. Roslindale would provide everything needed to write and send letters, including postage for seven first-class letters each week. Parents and guardians could visit twice a week for two hours. Lawyers and clergy could visit any day of the week between 9:00 A.M. and 7:00 P.M. Local phone calls, lasting five minutes, would be available six days a week. All staff, new and old, would be checked to ensure they were emotionally fit to work with children in a detention setting. Each young person would get a counselor to help with problems from being detained, and there would be one counseling supervisor for every 45 young people. All employees would receive regular ongoing training. Each young person's individual education needs would be met, with class sizes no larger than 12. Each young person would be examined by a doctor or nurse within 24 hours of arriving at Roslindale, and at least every four months after that. Mental health and emergency medical care would be available to all young people. Each young person would have at least 75 square feet of personal space, and there would be one common room for every 20 young people. Upon arrival, each young person would get a clean room and be responsible for keeping it clean afterward. Each student would get at least two hours of outdoor recreation on school days, and four hours on non-school days. Games, books, and magazines would be provided to young people. Required sleeping hours would not be more than 8 hours per night. New young people would receive clean mattresses, bedding, towels, toothbrushes, and toothpaste. Bedding would be cleaned weekly. All young people could shower or bathe daily, and towels would be changed twice weekly. Breakfast and an evening meal would be provided to all young people, with a snack available after the evening meal if it was served before 5:00 P.M. Physical punishment was strictly forbidden. Rules about allowed and forbidden behavior would be clearly explained to all young people upon arrival at Roslindale. Finally, any limits on rights due to behavior must come from written rules available to the young people, and a hearing must be held on the matter as soon as possible.

The defendants had eight months to make Roslindale fully follow the Consent Decree, or face closure. Five people were appointed to a Monitoring Board for two years. This board would send its findings and suggestions to both sides every two months for the first eight months, and then every three months after that. The Court (Judge Garrity) kept the authority to oversee the case. There is no court record or more information about how the case ultimately ended.

*   Local phone calls, lasting five minutes, would be available six days a week.
*   All staff, new and old, would be checked to ensure they were emotionally fit to work with children in a detention center.

*   Each young person's individual education needs would be met. Class sizes would be no larger than 12 students.
*   Each young person would be examined by a doctor or nurse within 24 hours of arriving at Roslindale. They would be checked at least every four months after that.
*   Mental health and emergency medical care would be available to all young people.
*   Each young person would have at least 75 square feet of personal space. There would be one common room for every 20 young people.
*   Upon arrival, each young person would get a clean room. They would be responsible for keeping it clean afterward.
*   Each student would get at least two hours of outdoor recreation on school days. On non-school days, they would get four hours.
*   Games, books, and magazines would be provided to young people.
*   Required sleeping hours would not be more than 8 hours per night.
*   New young people would receive clean mattresses, bedding, towels, toothbrushes, and toothpaste.
*   Bedding would be cleaned weekly.
*   All young people could shower or bathe daily. Towels would be changed twice weekly.
*   Breakfast and an evening meal would be provided to all young people. A snack would be available after the evening meal if it was served before 5:00 P.M.
*   Physical punishment was strictly forbidden.
*   Rules about allowed and forbidden behavior would be clearly explained to all young people upon arrival at Roslindale.
*   Finally, any limits on rights due to behavior must come from written rules that young people could see. A hearing must be held on the matter as soon as possible.

The defendants had eight months to make Roslindale fully follow the Consent Decree. If they failed, the center could be shut down. Five people were chosen for a Monitoring Board. They would serve for two years. This board would send its reports and suggestions to both sides. For the first eight months, reports would go out every two months. 3.transformed_text:
Back in 1975, a group of young people who were held at a place called the Judge J. Connelly Youth Center, or "Roslindale," in Massachusetts, decided to sue the government. They filed a lawsuit in federal court. They sued the Governor, saying that the conditions at Roslindale were so bad they actually violated their basic rights, which is what "unconstitutional" means. They asked the court to declare these conditions illegal and force the state to make improvements. Two groups, the Juvenile Court Advocacy Program and the Massachusetts Defenders Committee, helped these young people with their legal case.

Before a full trial could happen, both sides sat down and reached an agreement. This special agreement, called a "Consent Decree," was then approved by the court. Think of it like a binding contract that the court signs off on. On April 2, 1976, a federal judge named Wendell Arthur Garrity, Jr. in Massachusetts officially approved this agreement. Once approved, it became a final, powerful court order that everyone had to follow.

The Consent Decree stated that:
*   First, the Department of Youth Services (DYS) had to stop putting young people who were just waiting for their court date in the same areas as those who had already been sentenced and were waiting to be moved to a permanent facility. It's like separating students who are just visiting from those who are enrolled full-time.
*   Parents had to be told immediately when a young person arrived at Roslindale, and they also needed to know who their child's lawyer was.
*   Young people could send and get mail from anyone. If a package came, it could only be opened when the person it was for was present, just to make sure no forbidden items were inside.
*   Roslindale had to give young people everything they needed to write and send letters, including stamps for up to seven regular letters each week.
*   Parents and guardians could visit twice a week for two hours each time.
*   Lawyers and religious leaders could visit any day of the week, from 9:00 AM to 7:00 PM.
*   Young people could make local phone calls, five minutes long, six days a week.
*   All staff, both new and existing, had to be checked to make sure they were emotionally ready and fit to work with young people in a detention center.
*   Each young person would get a counselor to help them with any issues caused by being held there. And for every 45 young people, there would be one supervisor for the counselors.
*   All employees had to receive regular, ongoing training.
*   Each young person's individual learning needs had to be met, and class sizes couldn't be larger than 12 students.
*   Every young person had to be seen by a doctor or nurse within 24 hours of arriving at Roslindale, and then checked again at least every four months.
*   Mental health support and emergency medical care had to be available to all young people.
*   Each young person needed to have at least 75 square feet of their own personal space. Also, there had to be one common room for every 20 young people.
*   When they arrived, each young person would get a clean room, and then they would be responsible for keeping it clean themselves.
*   Each student would get at least two hours of outdoor time on school days, and four hours on days when there was no school.
*   Games, books, and magazines had to be provided to young people.
*   Young people couldn't be forced to sleep for more than 8 hours a night.
*   New young people would get clean mattresses, bedding, towels, toothbrushes, and toothpaste.
*   Bedding had to be cleaned weekly.
*   All young people could shower or bathe every day, and their towels would be changed twice a week.
*   Breakfast and an evening meal had to be provided. If the evening meal was served before 5:00 PM, a snack would also be available later.
*   Physical punishment was absolutely not allowed.
*   Rules about what was allowed and not allowed had to be clearly explained to all young people when they arrived at Roslindale.
*   Finally, if a young person's rights were limited because of their behavior, it had to be based on written rules that they could see, and a quick meeting (a "hearing") had to be held about it.

The state officials (the "defendants") were given eight months to make sure Roslindale fully followed all these rules. If they didn't, the center could be closed down. A special group of five people, called a "Monitoring Board," was set up for two years. Their job was to check on Roslindale and send reports and suggestions to both the young people's lawyers and the state officials. For the first eight months, they sent reports every two months, and after that, every three months. The court, with Judge Garrity in charge, kept the power to make sure the agreement was followed. We don't have any more court records or details about how this case finally wrapped up.

To oversee these changes, a five-person Monitoring Board was established for two years, tasked with regularly reporting its observations and suggestions to both sides. Judge Garrity maintained ongoing supervision to ensure the terms were met. Regrettably, no further public record exists detailing the ultimate outcome or long-term impact of this significant agreement.

original_case_data.summary:
On March 1, 1985, a class of juveniles confined at juvenile detention centers operated by the District of Columbia ("the District") filed a lawsuit against the District under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, in the Superior Court of the District of Columbia. They alleged unconstitutional conditions of confinement in violation of the juveniles' Fifth and Eighth Amendment rights. Plaintiffs specifically challenged the conditions of confinement at Cedar Knoll Youth Center and Oak Hill Youth Center, both in Laurel, Maryland, alleging that the facilities at Cedar Knoll were unfit for habitation and that rehabilitative services, including educational and vocational training services, mental health and medical services, and social and recreational services, were unconstitutionally and statutorily inadequate at both Centers. The complaint further alleged that a climate of violence existed at both Centers, and that policies concerning attorney-client communication and family visitation at both Centers violated the juveniles' rights. The plaintiffs, represented by the Public Defender Service and the ACLU National Prison Project, sought declaratory and injunctive relief.

On July 24, 1986, the Superior Court (Honorable Ricardo M. Urbina) approved and entered a consent decree ("the Decree"). The consent decree established a panel of three experts to determine the correct number of juveniles in the District in need of secure confinement, and develop a system for appropriate care of these juveniles. The Decree established procedural rules for staff discipline and training, recordkeeping, and discipline of juveniles; set forth detailed requirements for diagnostic procedures, cottage life, recreational, mental health, and social services, as well as education and vocational training programs; and required the District to submit a plan and timetable for resolving environmental health and safety concerns.

The Clearinghouse only has appellate decisions describing subsequent litigation, but it is clear that extensive litigation over the scope of the Decree followed. Following the panel's submission of a plan to the court, and the court's orders pursuant to this plan, the District appealed. The District of Columbia Court of Appeals (Chief Judge Rogers) found that the trial judge had exceeded his authority under the scope of the decree in certain respects. 571 A.2d 178 (D.C. Ct. App. 1990). The court of appeals did, however, find that the trial judge had not erred in finding that the District had "failed to meet its basic commitment under the Decree," and in imposing sanctions.

On September 5, 1990, the D.C. Court of Appeals (Judge Farrell) affirmed the lower court's ruling that plaintiffs' attorneys could be awarded fees for their work enforcing the Decree, but remanded the issue to the trial court because it had failed to adequately explain its reasoning as to the amount of fees awarded. 580 A.2d 1270 (D.C. Ct. App. 1990). Attorney's fees litigation continued over several years. In 1996, the plaintiffs' attorney submitted a bill for work done during the months of April, May, and June, 1996. Defendants contested, arguing that fees for any work done after passage of the Prison Litigation Reform Act ("PLRA") were subject to the PLRA fee cap. The District Court (Judge Richard A. Levie) held that the PLRA did not apply to juvenile facilities, but on September 3, 1998, the D.C. Court of Appeals (Judge Schwelb) reversed, holding that the PLRA's limitation on attorney fee awards did apply to attorneys whose clients were confined juveniles and that the fee cap did not violate due process. 717 A.2d 866 (D.C. 1998).

Meanwhile, on June 24, 1997, the D.C. Superior Court appointed a Special Master to assist the defendants "in identifying and correcting deficiencies in the provision of educational services required by the Consent Decree," because the defendants had repeatedly failed to bring the educational systems at the Centers into compliance with the Decree. In August 1998, the Special Master expressed concern over "certain personnel, resource, and training issues" at the Oak Hill Center, and the trial court appointed a receiver "to assume, ultimate control over the education system at Oak Hill.'" The District appealed, and the D.C. Court of Appeals (per curiam) held that, while the District had not fully complied with the Decree, there was not a sufficient basis for the imposition of such an extraordinary remedy. 738 A.2d 1206 (D.C. 1999). On May 15, 2000, the United States Supreme Court denied certiorari. 529 U.S. 1118 (2000).

The consent decree remained in effect for several subsequent decades. In 2015, the parties settled part of the case and agreed that the court would have less oversight responsibility going forward.

On February 5, 2020, the parties settled the remainder of the case and agreed to end the consent decree. The District pointed to various improvements it had made over the years, such as establishing a Department of Youth Rehabilitation Services, closing facilities (including Oak Hill) and opening new facilities, adding medical and behavioral health services, education, and other rehabilitative resources, and making facilities safer. The settlement required the District to create an Office of Independent Juvenile Justice Facilities Oversight (OIJJFO), which would make sure that the District was still meeting the goals of the consent decree. The court approved this settlement later that year, and the consent decree was terminated.

The OIJJFO was created in 2021, and the settlement mandated that it operate for at least three years. In November 2023, the District decided to fund the OIJJFO until at least September 2024. Subsequent news reports indicated that the OIJJFO would be funded through 2025 as well. These extensions of the OIJJFO occurred after allegations about dangerous conditions within the District's youth facilities, including staffing shortages, excessive confinement, sexual assault, and violent fights.
original_case_data.summary_short: On March 1, 1985, a class of juveniles confined at juvenile detention centers operated by the District of Columbia ("the District") filed a lawsuit in the Superior Court of the District of Columbia against the District. Plaintiffs alleged violations of the Due Process and Cruel and Unusual Punishment clauses under 42 U.S.C. § 1983. After complex litigation, the Court (Ricardo M. Urbina) awarded attorney fees to the plaintiff, though the amount was reversed on appeal and not stated by the courts; the Court also signed a consent decree to improve confinement conditions. The District did not comply and the Court granted receivership, but the decision was remanded for consideration of factors mentioned by the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. The consent decree continued until 2020, when the parties settled the case and court monitoring ended.

3.transformed_text:
After nearly 35 years of litigation concerning the conditions of confinement for juveniles, the District of Columbia and a class of confined juveniles ultimately settled the case, leading to the termination of a comprehensive consent decree and the establishment of an independent oversight body to ensure continued adherence to rehabilitative and safety standards.

**Key Results:**

*   **Case Initiation and Consent Decree:** In March 1985, a class of juveniles confined by the District of Columbia filed a 42 U.S.C. § 1983 lawsuit in the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, alleging unconstitutional conditions of confinement in violation of their Fifth and Eighth Amendment rights at Cedar Knoll and Oak Hill Youth Centers. Plaintiffs challenged unfit facilities, inadequate rehabilitative services (educational, vocational, mental health, medical, social, recreational), a climate of violence, and violations concerning attorney-client communication and family visitation. Seeking declaratory and injunctive relief, the parties entered a comprehensive consent decree in July 1986. This Decree established an expert panel for secure confinement needs, set procedural rules for staff and juvenile discipline, detailed requirements for various rehabilitative services, and mandated a plan for environmental health and safety.

*   **Extensive Litigation and Appellate Rulings:** The Decree's implementation led to extensive litigation. The D.C. Court of Appeals found the trial judge exceeded authority regarding the expert panel's plan but affirmed the District's failure to meet its basic commitment and upheld sanctions (571 A.2d 178). Attorney fee awards were affirmed but remanded for explanation (580 A.2d 1270), and the D.C. Court of Appeals later held the Prison Litigation Reform Act's (PLRA) attorney fee limitations applied to counsel for confined juveniles (717 A.2d 866). Despite the District's non-compliance with educational services, the D.C. Court of Appeals reversed the trial court's appointment of a receiver for Oak Hill's education system as an extraordinary remedy lacking sufficient basis (738 A.2d 1206), a decision upheld by the U.S. Supreme Court's denial of certiorari.

*   **Final Settlement and Decree Termination:** After decades under the consent decree, the parties partially settled in 2015, reducing court oversight. On February 5, 2020, the remaining issues were settled, terminating the decree. The District cited improvements, including the establishment of the Department of Youth Rehabilitation Services, facility changes (Oak Hill closure), and enhanced medical, behavioral health, educational, and rehabilitative resources. The settlement mandated creation of the Office of Independent Juvenile Justice Facilities Oversight (OIJJFO) to ensure the District's continued adherence to the decree's goals. The court approved this settlement, terminating the consent decree.

*   **Ongoing Oversight and Current Challenges:** The OIJJFO, established in 2021 with an initial three-year mandate, has received extended funding through at least September 2024, and reportedly through 2025. These extensions were prompted by persistent allegations of dangerous conditions within the District's youth facilities, including staffing shortages, excessive confinement, sexual assault, and violent fights, underscoring the ongoing need for independent monitoring despite the formal termination of the consent decree.

**DC Juvenile Confinement Case Settles After 35 Years, New Oversight Established**

*   **Who Sued Who?** A class of juveniles confined by the District of Columbia filed a 42 U.S.C. § 1983 lawsuit against the District in March 1985.
*   **Why?** Alleging unconstitutional conditions at Cedar Knoll and Oak Hill Youth Centers, plaintiffs cited unfit facilities, inadequate rehabilitative services (educational, vocational, mental health, medical, social, recreational), a violent climate, and violations of attorney-client/family visitation rights, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief.
*   **What Happened?** In July 1986, a comprehensive consent decree was entered, establishing an expert panel for secure confinement needs, setting procedural rules for staff and juvenile discipline, detailing requirements for various rehabilitative services, and mandating an environmental health and safety plan. Its implementation led to extensive litigation, including appellate rulings on trial judge authority, attorney fee limitations under the PLRA, and the reversal of a receiver's appointment for education despite District non-compliance. After decades, the parties settled, terminating the decree on February 5, 2020. The District cited improvements like the Department of Youth Rehabilitation Services, facility changes (Oak Hill closure), and enhanced medical, behavioral health, educational, and rehabilitative resources. The settlement mandated the creation of the Office of Independent Juvenile Justice Facilities Oversight (OIJJFO) in 2021 to ensure continued adherence to the decree's goals. The OIJJFO, initially mandated for three years, has received extensions through at least September 2024, and reportedly 2025, due to persistent allegations of dangerous conditions within youth facilities, including staffing shortages, excessive confinement, sexual assault, and violent fights, highlighting the ongoing need for independent monitoring.

On March 1, 1985, a group of young people held at juvenile detention centers run by the District of Columbia ("the District") sued the District in the D.C. Superior Court. They claimed the conditions they were held in were unconstitutional, violating their Fifth and Eighth Amendment rights. The lawsuit specifically targeted the Cedar Knoll Youth Center and Oak Hill Youth Center in Laurel, Maryland. The young people alleged that Cedar Knoll was not fit to live in, and that rehabilitation services—like education, job training, mental health care, medical care, and social and recreational activities—were not good enough at both centers, violating both the Constitution and laws. The lawsuit also claimed a violent atmosphere existed at both centers. Additionally, they argued that rules about talking with lawyers and family visits violated the young people's rights. The plaintiffs, represented by the Public Defender Service and the ACLU National Prison Project, asked the court to declare their rights and order changes.

On July 24, 1986, the Superior Court (Judge Ricardo M. Urbina) approved a settlement agreement, called a "consent decree." This agreement created a panel of three experts. Their job was to figure out how many young people in the District needed secure detention and to create a system for their proper care. The decree set up rules for staff discipline and training, record-keeping, and how to discipline young people. It also outlined detailed requirements for assessing young people, daily living arrangements, recreational, mental health, and social services, plus education and job training programs. Finally, it required the District to submit a plan and timeline for fixing health and safety problems.

Our records only include appeals court decisions about what happened next, but it's clear that many legal disputes followed regarding what the settlement agreement covered. After the expert panel submitted a plan to the court, and the court issued orders based on this plan, the District appealed. The District of Columbia Court of Appeals (Chief Judge Rogers) ruled that the trial judge had gone beyond his authority in some parts of the agreement. However, the appeals court also found that the trial judge was correct in deciding that the District had "failed to meet its basic commitment under the Decree" and in punishing them for it.

On September 5, 1990, the D.C. Court of Appeals (Judge Farrell) upheld the lower court's decision that the plaintiffs' lawyers could receive fees for their work enforcing the agreement. But the appeals court sent the issue back to the trial court because it hadn't clearly explained how it decided the amount of fees. Legal battles over attorney's fees continued for several years. In 1996, the plaintiffs' attorney submitted a bill for work from April, May, and June of that year. The District challenged this, arguing that fees for any work after the Prison Litigation Reform Act ("PLRA") was passed should be limited by the PLRA's fee cap. The District Court (Judge Richard A. Levie) initially ruled that the PLRA did not apply to juvenile facilities. However, on September 3, 1998, the D.C. Court of Appeals (Judge Schwelb) overturned that decision. The appeals court ruled that the PLRA's limit on attorney fee awards *did* apply to lawyers representing young people in detention, and that this fee cap was constitutional.

Meanwhile, on June 24, 1997, the D.C. Superior Court appointed a Special Master. This person was to help the District "find and fix problems with the education services required by the settlement agreement," because the District had repeatedly failed to follow the agreement regarding education at the centers. In August 1998, the Special Master raised concerns about "staffing, resources, and training problems" at the Oak Hill Center. The trial court then appointed a receiver, someone to take "full control over the education system at Oak Hill." The District appealed this decision. The D.C. Court of Appeals ruled that while the District had not fully followed the agreement, there wasn't enough reason to impose such an extreme solution. On May 15, 2000, the United States Supreme Court refused to hear the case.

The settlement agreement stayed in place for several more decades. In 2015, the parties settled part of the case. They agreed that the court would oversee things less closely from then on.

On February 5, 2020, the parties settled the rest of the case and agreed to end the settlement agreement. The District highlighted various improvements it had made over the years. These included creating a Department of Youth Rehabilitation Services, closing old facilities (like Oak Hill) and opening new ones, adding medical and mental health services, education, and other rehabilitation programs, and making facilities safer. The settlement required the District to create an Office of Independent Juvenile Justice Facilities Oversight (OIJJFO). This office would ensure the District continued to meet the settlement agreement's goals. The court approved this final settlement later that year, and the consent decree officially ended.

The OIJJFO was created in 2021, and the settlement required it to operate for at least three years. In November 2023, the District decided to fund the OIJJFO until at least September 2024. Later news reports showed that the OIJJFO would be funded through 2025 as well. These extensions of the OIJJFO happened after claims about dangerous conditions within the District's youth facilities, including not enough staff, too much time in isolation, sexual assault, and violent fights.

3.transformed_text:
On March 1, 1985, a group of young people held at youth detention centers run by the local government of Washington D.C. sued the D.C. government in a local court. They said the conditions were against the Constitution, violating their rights to fair treatment and protection from cruel punishment. Think of it like a school having rules that go against your basic rights as a student. They pointed to two specific places: Cedar Knoll and Oak Hill Youth Centers in Maryland. They claimed Cedar Knoll wasn't even safe or healthy to live in. And they said important services, like education, job training, mental health care, medical care, and fun activities, were just not good enough at both centers. They argued this went against the Constitution and other laws. The lawsuit also painted a picture of a violent environment at both places. Plus, they said the rules about talking to their lawyers and having family visits weren't fair and violated their rights. The young people, with help from groups like the Public Defender Service and the ACLU, asked the court to officially say what their rights were and to make the D.C. government change things.

On July 24, 1986, a judge named Ricardo M. Urbina approved an agreement to settle the case. This agreement, called a "consent decree," is like a formal promise or contract approved by the court, that both sides—the young people and the D.C. government—agreed to follow. It set up a team of three experts. Their mission was to figure out how many young people in D.C. needed to be in secure places (like a locked-down dorm in a boarding school, but for safety) and to create a plan for how to properly care for them. The agreement also laid out rules for how staff should be trained and disciplined, how records should be kept, and how to discipline the young people themselves. It also had detailed rules for checking on young people's needs, their daily living conditions, and the quality of their fun activities, mental health care, social services, education, and job training. Finally, it demanded that the D.C. government provide a plan and a schedule to fix any health and safety issues.

We only have records from higher courts about what happened next, but it's clear there were many arguments about what the agreement actually meant or covered. After the expert team gave their plan to the court, and the court issued orders based on it, the D.C. government appealed, meaning they asked a higher court to review the decision. The D.C. Court of Appeals (a higher court) said that the first judge had overstepped his boundaries in some parts of the agreement. Imagine if a teacher gave you a punishment that wasn't allowed by the school rules. But the appeals court also agreed that the D.C. government had "failed to keep its basic promises" from the agreement and that the judge was right to penalize them for it.

Later, in 1990, the D.C. Court of Appeals again said that the lawyers for the young people could get paid for their work to make sure the agreement was followed. But they sent the case back to the first court because the judge hadn't clearly explained *how* he decided the amount of money the lawyers should get. Arguments over these lawyer fees went on for years. In 1996, the young people's lawyer sent a bill for work done over a few months. The D.C. government fought this, saying that a new law called the Prison Litigation Reform Act (PLRA) meant there was a limit, or "cap," on how much lawyers could be paid for work done after that law was passed. The first court initially said this new law didn't apply to youth detention centers. But in 1998, the D.C. Court of Appeals disagreed and reversed that decision. The higher court said that the PLRA's limit on lawyer fees *did* apply to lawyers helping young people in detention, and that this limit was fair under the Constitution.

Around the same time, in 1997, the D.C. court brought in a "Special Master." Think of a Special Master as an independent expert, like a consultant, appointed by the court to help make sure things are going right and to fix problems. This person's job was to help the D.C. government "find and fix problems with the education services" they were supposed to provide, because the government kept failing to follow the agreement when it came to schooling at the centers. In 1998, the Special Master pointed out issues like not enough staff, resources, or training at the Oak Hill Center. So, the court then appointed a "receiver," which is like putting someone else completely in charge of the education system at Oak Hill to make sure changes actually happened. The D.C. government appealed this decision. The D.C. Court of Appeals said that even though the D.C. government hadn't fully kept its promises, taking over the education system was too extreme a step. Later, in 2000, the highest court in the country, the U.S. Supreme Court, chose not to hear the case, meaning the appeals court's decision stood.

This agreement stayed in effect for many more years. In 2015, parts of the case were settled. Both sides agreed that the court wouldn't need to watch over things as closely anymore.

Then, in 2020, both sides finally settled the rest of the case and agreed to end the entire agreement. The D.C. government pointed out all the improvements it had made over the years. These included creating a special department for youth rehabilitation, closing old centers like Oak Hill and opening new ones, adding better medical and mental health care, education, and other programs to help young people, and making the facilities safer. The final agreement required the D.C. government to create a new office called the Office of Independent Juvenile Justice Facilities Oversight (OIJJFO). This office's job would be to make sure the D.C. government kept meeting the goals of the original agreement, even after it officially ended. The court approved this final deal later that year, and the original agreement officially came to an end.

The OIJJFO office was set up in 2021 and was supposed to operate for at least three years. In late 2023, the D.C. government decided to keep funding this office until at least September 2024. News reports later showed it would even be funded through 2025. These extensions happened because there were still concerns and reports about dangerous conditions in D.C.'s youth facilities, including not enough staff, young people being isolated too much, sexual assault, and violent fights.

0.text:
On March 1, 1985, a class of juveniles confined at juvenile detention centers operated by the District of Columbia ("the District") filed a lawsuit against the District under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, in the Superior Court of the District of Columbia. They alleged unconstitutional conditions of confinement in violation of the juveniles' Fifth and Eighth Amendment rights. Plaintiffs specifically challenged the conditions of confinement at Cedar Knoll Youth Center and Oak Hill Youth Center, both in Laurel, Maryland, alleging that the facilities at Cedar Knoll were unfit for habitation and that rehabilitative services, including educational and vocational training services, mental health and medical services, and social and recreational services, were unconstitutionally and statutorily inadequate at both Centers. The complaint further alleged that a climate of violence existed at both Centers, and that policies concerning attorney-client communication and family visitation at both Centers violated the juveniles' rights. The plaintiffs, represented by the Public Defender Service and the ACLU National Prison Project, sought declaratory and injunctive relief.

On July 24, 1986, the Superior Court (Honorable Ricardo M. Urbina) approved and entered a consent decree ("the Decree"). The consent decree established a panel of three experts to determine the correct number of juveniles in the District in need of secure confinement, and develop a system for appropriate care of these juveniles. The Decree established procedural rules for staff discipline and training, recordkeeping, and discipline of juveniles; set forth detailed requirements for diagnostic procedures, cottage life, recreational, mental health, and social services, as well as education and vocational training programs; and required the District to submit a plan and timetable for resolving environmental health and safety concerns.

The Clearinghouse only has appellate decisions describing subsequent litigation, but it is clear that extensive litigation over the scope of the Decree followed. Following the panel's submission of a plan to the court, and the court's orders pursuant to this plan, the District appealed. The District of Columbia Court of Appeals (Chief Judge Rogers) found that the trial judge had exceeded his authority under the scope of the decree in certain respects. 571 A.2d 178 (D.C. Ct. App. 1990). The court of appeals did, however, find that the trial judge had not erred in finding that the District had "failed to meet its basic commitment under the Decree," and in imposing sanctions.

On September 5, 1990, the D.C. Court of Appeals (Judge Farrell) affirmed the lower court's ruling that plaintiffs' attorneys could be awarded fees for their work enforcing the Decree, but remanded the issue to the trial court because it had failed to adequately explain its reasoning as to the amount of fees awarded. 580 A.2d 1270 (D.C. Ct. App. 1990). Attorney's fees litigation continued over several years. In 1996, the plaintiffs' attorney submitted a bill for work done during the months of April, May, and June, 1996. Defendants contested, arguing that fees for any work done after passage of the Prison Litigation Reform Act ("PLRA") were subject to the PLRA fee cap. The District Court (Judge Richard A. Levie) held that the PLRA did not apply to juvenile facilities, but on September 3, 1998, the D.C. Court of Appeals (Judge Schwelb) reversed, holding that the PLRA's limitation on attorney fee awards did apply to attorneys whose clients were confined juveniles and that the fee cap did not violate due process. 717 A.2d 866 (D.C. 1998).

Meanwhile, on June 24, 1997, the D.C. Superior Court appointed a Special Master to assist the defendants "in identifying and correcting deficiencies in the provision of educational services required by the Consent Decree," because the defendants had repeatedly failed to bring the educational systems at the Centers into compliance with the Decree. In August 1998, the Special Master expressed concern over "certain personnel, resource, and training issues" at the Oak Hill Center, and the trial court appointed a receiver "to assume, ultimate control over the education system at Oak Hill.'" The District appealed, and the D.C. Court of Appeals (per curiam) held that, while the District had not fully complied with the Decree, there was not a sufficient basis for the imposition of such an extraordinary remedy. 738 A.2d 1206 (D.C. 1999). On May 15, 2000, the United States Supreme Court denied certiorari. 529 U.S. 1118 (2000).

The consent decree remained in effect for several subsequent decades. In 2015, the parties settled part of the case and agreed that the court would have less oversight responsibility going forward.

On February 5, 2020, the parties settled the remainder of the case and agreed to end the consent decree. The District pointed to various improvements it had made over the years, such as establishing a Department of Youth Rehabilitation Services, closing facilities (including Oak Hill) and opening new facilities, adding medical and behavioral health services, education, and other rehabilitative resources, and making facilities safer. The settlement required the District to create an Office of Independent Juvenile Justice Facilities Oversight (OIJJFO), which would make sure that the District was still meeting the goals of the consent decree. The court approved this settlement later that year, and the consent decree was terminated.

The OIJJFO was created in 2021, and the settlement mandated that it operate for at least three years. In November 2023, the District decided to fund the OIJJFO until at least September 2024. Subsequent news reports indicated that the OIJJFO would be funded through 2025 as well. These extensions of the OIJJFO occurred after allegations about dangerous conditions within the District's youth facilities, including staffing shortages, excessive confinement, sexual assault, and violent fights.

1.transformed_text:
From the perspective of a legal historian, the story of juvenile confinement in the District of Columbia unfolds as a protracted struggle for fundamental rights, marked by periods of intense litigation and negotiated reform.

The narrative began on March 1, 1985, when a class of juveniles, through their legal advocates, initiated a lawsuit. Their purpose was clear: to challenge the District of Columbia over what they alleged were unconstitutional conditions within its juvenile detention centers, specifically Cedar Knoll and Oak Hill. They sought to compel the District to provide humane and rehabilitative environments, arguing that the existing facilities were unfit, lacked essential services like education and mental health care, and fostered a climate of violence. This legal action was a strategic move to secure a court order that would force systemic change and uphold the juveniles' Fifth and Eighth Amendment rights.

Rather than proceeding to a full trial, the parties engaged in negotiations, culminating in a consent decree approved by the Superior Court on July 24, 1986. This was a pivotal moment, as it allowed both sides to define a path forward through agreement, avoiding the uncertainties and prolonged conflict of litigation. For the plaintiffs, it secured an early, comprehensive commitment from the District to address the alleged deficiencies. For the District, it offered a structured framework for reform, potentially limiting the scope of court intervention compared to a judge-imposed remedy after a trial. The decree established a detailed blueprint for improving care, services, and safety within the facilities.

Despite the decree, extensive litigation over its implementation followed. The District, seeking to rein in the trial court's oversight and limit the extent of the reforms it was compelled to undertake, appealed certain orders. While the District had agreed to the decree, it strategically challenged what it perceived as judicial overreach, aiming to reduce the burden of compliance. However, the appellate court affirmed the core finding that the District had "failed to meet its basic commitment," indicating that while the scope might be debated, the underlying problem of non-compliance persisted.

A crucial battle for the plaintiffs' legal team unfolded over attorney's fees. Securing these fees was essential to sustain their long-term efforts in monitoring and enforcing the decree, ensuring the District remained accountable. The District, by contesting the fees and invoking the Prison Litigation Reform Act, sought to limit the financial burden of the litigation and, implicitly, to make it more difficult for plaintiffs' counsel to continue their oversight, thereby potentially reducing the pressure for full compliance.

Years later, the trial court's growing frustration with the District's persistent non-compliance, particularly regarding educational services, led to the appointment of a Special Master in June 1997, and subsequently, a receiver in August 1998, to directly oversee reforms at Oak Hill. These were escalating measures, designed to compel the District to meet its obligations. The District's appeal against the receiver's appointment was a strong defensive move, aiming to preserve its autonomy and resist what it viewed as an extreme intrusion into its operational control, arguing that such a drastic remedy was unwarranted despite its acknowledged shortcomings. The appellate court agreed, finding insufficient basis for such an extraordinary remedy.

The consent decree remained in effect for several subsequent decades, a testament to the deep-seated nature of the issues and the ongoing struggle for reform. In 2015, the parties reached a partial settlement, and finally, on February 5, 2020, they settled the remainder of the case, agreeing to terminate the decree. For the District, ending the decree was a goal to regain full control over its facilities, asserting that its reforms had reached a point where external judicial supervision was no longer required. For the plaintiffs, agreeing to terminate the decree, after decades of enforcement, implied a belief that a sustainable framework for oversight, like the newly created Office of Independent Juvenile Justice Facilities Oversight (OIJJFO), could now ensure continued progress without direct court intervention.

The creation of the OIJJFO in 2021, and its subsequent extensions, underscore a lingering recognition that vigilance is still required. The continued funding of this oversight body, especially in the wake of renewed allegations of dangerous conditions within the District's youth facilities, suggests that the historical struggle for humane and safe conditions for confined juveniles remains an ongoing narrative, even as the formal legal battle has concluded. It reflects a societal commitment, perhaps born from decades of litigation, to ensure that the hard-won reforms endure.
